text:
Hi eupers! :smile: Got a question/challenge..

Given that end user programming means your demographic is basically "everyone", I'm having trouble planning my work and what demos/releases to do, since I don't have a clear vision of my target audience!

In the past I've considered education (Onex runs on Micro:Bits), AR, VR, 3D games, "creative coders" (visuals, music), mobile automation (like Tasker), mobile database (like Airtable), etc, etc..

But I also don't want to be locked in to or biased to any particular domain.

What do you folk think or do about this conundrum?

elements.text: Hi eupers!

Got a question/challenge..

Given that end user programming means your demographic is basically "everyone", I'm having trouble planning my work and what demos/releases to do, since I don't have a clear vision of my target audience!

In the past I've considered education (Onex runs on Micro:Bits), AR, VR, 3D games, "creative coders" (visuals, music), mobile automation (like Tasker), mobile database (like Airtable), etc, etc..

But I also don't want to be locked in to or biased to any particular domain.

What do you folk think or do about this conundrum?

text: define "personas" and use cases (aka verticals) and focus on a couple to prove that the solution can solve at least some problems while trying the keep the platform generic, when I add a feature to advance on one use case I check that the solution applies in general.

elements.text: define "personas" and use cases (aka verticals) and focus on a couple to prove that the solution can solve at least some problems while trying the keep the platform generic, when I add a feature to advance on one use case I check that the solution applies in general.

text: For example I'm thinking on focusing on firebase users and "waiting room screens", that doesn't mean my platform is just for that, but it has to solve some problems good enough at first, they serve as a clear objective to complete.

elements.text: For example I'm thinking on focusing on firebase users and "waiting room screens", that doesn't mean my platform is just for that, but it has to solve some problems good enough at first, they serve as a clear objective to complete.

text: a good set of use cases are ones that don't overlap much, so if you implement a feature to advance on one vertical it will be clear on the others if it's general or not

elements.text: a good set of use cases are ones that don't overlap much, so if you implement a feature to advance on one vertical it will be clear on the others if it's general or not

text: :smile:

Up to now I've been thinking:
"People can:
 - program spreadsheets
 - or something database-like such as Airtable, MobiDB or MementoDB
 - create little automations on their phones using Tasker, Macrodroid or Automate
 - or use an IFTTT rule
 - make games with Pocket Code, Roblox, Ready Maker, even Minecraft
 - make apps with Sketchware
"
which are *very* broad categories to choose to compete with!

text: one thing i think could be fruitful is to look up a class of products people use spreadsheets for—eg, take personal finance. and then ask “why don’t people do this unless they’re really super comfortable with spreadsheets?” like i really should have a personal budget in an excel document but both the interface and automation seem really lacking. not to say: make mint or truebill, but “if i were to make a flexible, semi-automated mint, what primitives would fall out for data entry, visualization, manipulation” etc

text: but i think there are a lot of things that we look at with spreadsheets as “solved problems” that are actually people who happen to be excel experts desperately duct taping together half-solutions that serve like 3% of the market tops

elements.text: but i think there are a lot of things that we look at with spreadsheets as “solved problems” that are actually people who happen to be excel experts desperately duct taping together half-solutions that serve like 3% of the market tops

text: One of the problems with spreadsheet usage stats is that a significant fraction of spreadsheets in the wild exercise nothing more than simple arithmetic; say monthly sums and a grand total of the yearly. One would be hard pressed to improve the usability of the system, when the user is doing so little data manipulation. Spreadsheets give the user 100% visibility of the data, but hide all the code. As long as you have negligible amounts of code this tradeoff works great. But i think most people would agree that spreadsheets are quite dangerous; so easy to remove a row without any trace of that mistake, and it is easy to make errors in formula ranges. The core functionality is really mostly unchanged since Frankston & Bricklin invented the category so long ago. I do think that an easier spreadsheet could thrive that has more safety checks against bonehead mistakes. So much of Excel's evolution has been to add rarely used complex features. I see Excel as the poor-man's database; it works remarkably well up to a million rows then it poops out. Having made a spreadsheet back in the day, it actually a pretty easy thing to program in the core, but all the graphical niceties make it an extremely complex beast to program.

text: Good points. One way of looking at spreadsheets is that they took something people did on paper and made it lively (could do calculations, rename and rearrange rows and columns, etc) in ways that you wish paper could do. What other things do people (even programmers) do on paper that they wish could be lively?

text: idk if anyone else has arranged research/arguments for an essay with index cards but for me the combination of physicality + whatever it is i’m able to tenuously maintain in my head is a way more pleasant way of thinking about information-rich decisions than anything i’ve been able to accomplish on a computer (including scrivener, which is a mac app which expressly attempts to replace thus workflow)

elements.text: idk if anyone else has arranged research/arguments for an essay with index cards but for me the combination of physicality + whatever it is i’m able to tenuously maintain in my head is a way more pleasant way of thinking about information-rich decisions than anything i’ve been able to accomplish on a computer (including scrivener, which is a mac app which expressly attempts to replace thus workflow)

text: it is so much easier to flip index cards around, pile them, filter them, aggregate them with your hands than it is with existing models and keyboard shortcuts

elements.text: it is so much easier to flip index cards around, pile them, filter them, aggregate them with your hands than it is with existing models and keyboard shortcuts

text: FWIW, it’s actually even worse than Edward is talking about: the vast majority of excel users have never written a formula at all. The primary use of spreadsheets is purely for organization. This is why we’re seeing something like airtable start to gain traction - it focuses explicitly on just that aspect and leaves calculation mostly behind.

elements.text: FWIW, it’s actually even worse than Edward is talking about: the vast majority of excel users have never written a formula at all. The primary use of spreadsheets is purely for organization. This is why we’re seeing something like airtable start to gain traction - it focuses explicitly on just that aspect and leaves calculation mostly behind.

text: When we dug into it more, we found that almost all cases of numerical work in spreadsheets revolved around financial modeling. If you really wanted to improve things you’d probably be better off purpose building something for that.

elements.text: When we dug into it more, we found that almost all cases of numerical work in spreadsheets revolved around financial modeling. If you really wanted to improve things you’d probably be better off purpose building something for that.
